phrase.item: There was a man who worked very very hard, but his work did not have any blessing.
[One day] his wife told him, "You are not earning in an ethical way. You should go to a certain place,
for example, 110 or 120 kilometers away from this place.
It is said that there is a man who earns in an ethical way."
The man left — the man who used to work very hard but [all his earnings] would enter through the door and exit through the chimney.
He kept the man [he was going to see] in his mind and left. He worked there [in that place] in the fall.
He cut the animal dung fuel and used a flat wooden shovel to fill a big wooden basket. Then the man asked him, "What?"
The newcomer replied, "Can I please also work with you?
I work so hard but it never brings any blessings.
It enters through the door and exits through the chimney."
The [local] man said, "Ok, whatever I do you should do the same."
They both had wooden shovel in their hands and filled the big wooden basket with animal dung fuel. Whatever that man did, the other man followed him.
In winter they collected animal dung and put it all in order. In spring each of them took a yak in their hands [to plow the field].
They did this until afternoon and evening.
So this is what they did, in summer they both watered the fields, in fall they both cut the grass and did the separating [of it from the grain].
The man copied whatever the other one did, the one who earned in an ethical way.
At the end they gathered in the harvest and the other man said, "Okay, it's been a year, now allow me to leave, with my earning in an ethical way."
[The local man] gave him two coins of money,
only two coins, both silver.
‎‎not gold, but silver [coins].
The man cried inside, and his tears almost came out. And he said to himself, "Oh, my wife's face is black ["it's my wife's fault"], she told me to earn in an ethical way, so it's only two coins.
This is not earning an ethical way at all. Oh, she has burned me."
"Don't worry,"
said the man who gave him the money.
[The local] said, "This is a lot of money, even your grandchildren will use and it won't be used up.
This is earning in an ethical way,
don't think of anything bad."
He left there sad and kept walking. On the way he met two children. They had a cat with a rope on it's neck with them.
The man said, "Why don't you give the cat to your uncle [me]?"
They asked, "So what do you give us in [exchange]?"
He replied, "I will give you money."
‎‎He gave them a silver coin and took the cat. He put it [the cat] inside [his coat]
çand, "tu jan sakər çiz rand?" çand, "uz savər pɨl randəm". He was wearing a leather coat, he put [the cat] up his sleeve, it was wide enough.
Then he reached a place where people where living.
He entered a house and saw a man was holding [food] in his hand.
[The newcomer] asked, "Hey, what kind of person you are that you are standing and eating?"
He relied, "It is impossible to sit down here".
He asked, "How come, impossible?"
He replied, "There are plenty of mice here, they can jump onto person's face."
"Mice do not have [right] to do so"- said the man.
He flexed and [it] made the sound "meow".
All the mice disappeared.
The mice sensed the smell of the cat, but still they came out and checked.
The [newcomer] told the man, "Sit" and
the other said, "Well, there is a mystery with you.
Usually these mice are not like this, even if someone is standing they try to jump up. So there is something with you".
[The newcomer] replied, "Nothing!"
At night, while [the man there] slept, the [newcomer] let the cat out.
In the morning when he woke up, he saw that the cat had stacked up all the mice, the house was almost full of them.
"What is 'tal'?",
"The cat stacked all the mice." [The owner] woke up in the morning and saw the house full of [dead] mice,
and said, "You have such a great animal with you.
Why don't you give it to me?"
He replied, "[Give me] as much gold [as the dog] is tall."
He replied, "Oh, its height,"
then this man held the cat up by its tail and lifted it up. With its two [front] feet on the [ground] and going up to its tail, it's pretty tall.
With its two feet on the ground and tail up to here,
he held by its tail.
[The owner] said, "This is too much".
When he held it by the root of its tail,
it went as high up as his knee.
He asked for a bag of [gold] and [the other man] made a bag full of gold.
The cat's height, not to the end of the tail but to its root. Up to the root of its tail.
The back feet up in the air.
He held its tail and asked, "So give me up to here."
He replied, "That much I will give you."
He gave the man a bag of mixed gold and silver and took the cat in exchange.
[The owner] was rich, he had a lot of gold and silver.
Then [the newcomer] left.
He kept walking but didn't reach his destination. At night he came under a sycamore where he hid himself and slept.
‎‎He used [the bag] as a pillow.
Later, there were another two children, they had a dog with them.
The [man] asked, "Why don't you guys give your dog to your uncle [me]?"
They replied, "What will you give in exchange?"
The man said, "I will give you money."
He gave the silver coin and took the dog.
He took the dog and left.
He stayed under a sycamore and a thorn kind of tree. When the man fell asleep, a demon came to catch him and the dog pulled [the demon] from behind.
The man found himself safe, but then he saw that [the demon] was looming over the dog. Then these two together and almost killed the [demon].
He was about to die and the man asked him, "Where is your treasure room?"
The demon asked. "Let me stay alive", and he went on, "My treasure rooms are seven feet from here," so then he dug up to the knee.
"My treasure room door will be visible from both sides.
‎‎I have seven treasure rooms."
He went and dug there. Then he returned and killed the [demon].
He killed the demon and returned to his house.
He reached the place next to his wife,
the gold was on his back.
His wife asked him, "How was it?"
He replied, "Well, you told me [different], but he gave me only two coins money". He left his bag somewhere close by, "What can be done with only two coins?" [said the wife] "
You said to earn in an ethical way, so here it is.
You lied."
In fact he was happy, but didn't tell her at the beginning. He said, "You are a woman from the left side of the hand, so you weren't right".
She said, "I told you the truth, you don't seem as if you were unlucky.
It really worked for you, you are lying to me."
Then he told the truth saying, "Yes, wife, indeed, When he gave me [the two coins] at the beginning, my tears almost came out.
I thought what can be done with this. So, I gave one coin and got the cat.
I exchanged the cat.
Then with this dog, a demon [was killed] and we got his seven treasure rooms."
Later, they hired builders and they built a castle there.
The king's castle was there on the other side in Afghanistan, but the castle for the man was on this side.
They got rich,
and lived well.
Seven rooms of treasure, full of gold and silver.
So, they became rich.
They hired servants and bought yaks to work in fields and slowly their wealth and servants grew more and that place turned into a city. This is what the poor man became.
